questions.question_text: Which two features implement one-to-one translation of a source IP address while allowing the source port to change? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
DIPP
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-networking-admin/nat/configure-nat/translate-internal-client-ip-addresses-to-your-public-ip-address-source-dipp-nat
Fallback Port
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClRMCA0

Selected Answer: AC
Dynamic IP (DIP) → Translates the source IP address to a new IP address from a pool, but allows the source port to change if needed.

Static IP → Maps one source IP address to a specific translated IP address, but the source port can still change if necessary.

Why not the other options

B. Dynamic IP and Port (DIPP)
DIPP allows multiple source IPs to be translated to a single IP using different source ports.
This is many-to-one NAT, not one-to-one.

D. Dynamic IP / Port Fallback
This is not a NAT type, but rather a fallback method used when the preferred NAT type (DIPP) runs out of available ports.

Selected Answer: BD
Looking at the below:
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/networking/nat/source-nat-and-destination-nat/source-nat
I would say B and D, is best fit. Reading the doc, and if this was a single answer it would be B.

Its not Static IP as this does not do port translation
Dynamic IP has an option to use DIPP

A. Dynamic IP123 D. Dynamic IP / Port Fallback2

Dynamic IP allows the one-to-one, dynamic translation of a source IP address only (no port number) to the next available address in the NAT address pool123. The size of the NAT pool should be equal to the number of internal hosts that require address translations23.
Dynamic IP / Port Fallback is an advanced option in Dynamic IP that enables the use of Dynamic IP and Port (DIPP) addresses when necessary

Selected Answer: AC
It's a really trick one!!!

Because here in this link, we can see that a 1:1 NAT should be A/C:

 https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClhwCAC

Dynamic IP: For a given source IP address, the firewall translates the source IP to an IP in the defined pool or range. The mapping is not port based, which makes this a one-to-one mapping as long as the session lasts.....

Static IP: Use this translation type to translate a single source address to a specific public address. This is typically used to expose a server (email, web or any application) externally using a translated address that will not change. Use the Static IP mapping type to translate an entire address range to a specific address range, a one-to-one mapping. The number of source IPs using this policy must exactly match the translated range. This is typically used to resolve overlapping IP ranges when merging networks. The policy shown here translates all source addresses with at 10.20.1.x address destined to the Corp Zone to a matching address in the 10.30.1.x range.

comments.content:
There is a table at URL below that has a column on whether the source port changes. With DIPP the source port changes and same with Fallback.
 https://live.paloaltonetworks.com/twzvq79624/attachments/twzvq79624/members_discuss/15121/1/TechNote_UnderstandingNAT.pdf

discussion.content:
From the Palo Alto website:

• Dynamic IP/Port (DIPP): used for outbound traffic; multiple clients can use the same public IP address(es) with different source port numbers

• Dynamic IP: used for outbound traffic; private source addresses translate to the next available address in a range

• Static IP: used for inbound or outbound traffic; can be used to change the source or the
destination IP address, with the source or destination port unchanged. When used to map a
single public IP address to multiple private servers and services, destination ports can stay the same or be directed to different destination ports.

Selected Answer: AC
A-C
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/networking/nat/nat-configuration-examples/destination-nat-exampleone-to-one-mappinghttps://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/networking/nat/nat-configuration-examples/destination-nat-exampleone-to-one-mappinghttps://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/networking/nat/nat-configuration-examples/destination-nat-exampleone-to-one-mapping
A and C. Both does 1:1 ip translation, allowing source port to change. DIPP is 1:Many

questions.question_text: What are three ways application characteristics are used? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABE
Correct Answer ABE
Correct Answer ABE

not sure why not C
you can use Characteristics during the application group configuration
objects>applications groups>add>browse then you can filter by Characteristics

Selected Answer: ABE
Correct: 
A. As a setting to define a new custom application
B. As a global filter in the Application Command Center (ACC)
E. As an attribute to define an application filter

Incorrect:
C. As an attribute to define an application group
D. As an object to define Security policies
I checked in the firewall. Characteristics aren't included in C + D.

Selected Answer: ABE
ABE is correct

This is correct, in the global filter in the ACC you can add app characteristics. A is correct and E is correct. C is iffy but in this case I would say it is not correct because yes I can search for apps regarding to risk level 5 but I have to add one by one by one. However, with application filter I can click on risk level 5 and boom it adds them all at once instead of me going to add them one by one.
I think ACE

choices.E: As an attribute to define an application filter
choices.D: As an object to define Security policies
choices.B: As a global filter in the Application Command Center (ACC)
choices.C: As an attribute to define an application group
choices.A: As a setting to define a new custom application

discussion.content:
C. Vulnerability Protection1 D. Anti-spyware2

Vulnerability Protection: This profile provides protection against exploits that target known software vulnerabilities2. You can configure it to block IP addresses for a specific time interval1.
Anti-spyware: This profile provides protection against spyware downloads2. It can also be configured to block IP addresses.

Selected Answer: CD
Correct:
C. Vulnerability Protection
D. Anti-spyware

Selected Answer: CD
Block-IP are valid on both Vulnerability Protection and Anti-Spyware

Selected Answer: CD
Correct:
C. Vulnerability Protection
D. Anti-spyware

I checked with the firewall.

Selected Answer: CD
C & D are correct

Selected Answer: CD
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-web-interface-help/objects/objects-security-profiles/actions-in-security-profiles
Agreed, C&D are correct
C & D should be the Answer

questions.question_text: In which two Security Profiles can an action equal to the block IP feature be configured? (Choose two.)

choices.A: When traffic matches a corresponding Security Profile
choices.D: Every time the firewall drops a connection
choices.B: When traffic matches any Security policy
choices.C: Every time a session is blocked

questions.question_text: When is an event displayed under threat logs?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I think it's the A too

Selected Answer: A
Found at:

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/monitoring/view-and-manage-logs/log-types-and-severity-levels/threat-logs#:~:text=Threat%20logs%20display%20entries%20when,security%20rule%20on%20the%20firewall.

I think the A
. A Threat log displays entries when the traffic matches
one of the Security profiles attached to a Security policy rule on the firewall.

Selected Answer: D
"A" sounds so correct until you sit back and think, "Active Directory" isn't a thing on a LAN or WAN. It's an LDAP running on multiple domain controllers. "Monitor AD" isn't really a thing. Monitor Domain Controllers is.

D
To ensure the most comprehensive mapping of users, you must monitor all domain controllers that process authentication for users you want to map. You might need to install multiple User-ID agents to efficiently monitor all of your resources.

Selected Answer: D
Active domain controller

Selected Answer: A
Server Monitoring -> Active Directory

A. Active Directory monitoring12

Active Directory monitoring allows the User-ID agent to monitor the security logs of Active Directory domain controllers for login events12. This information is used to map IP addresses to usernames12. The User-ID agent can monitor up to 100 servers, of which up to 50 can be syslog senders1. To collect all of the required mappings, the User-ID agent must connect to all servers that your users log in to in order to monitor the security log files on all servers that contain login events

Selected Answer: D
I will go with D based on Palo's documentation:

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/user-id/map-ip-addresses-to-users/configure-user-mapping-using-the-windows-user-id-agent/configure-the-windows-based-user-id-agent-for-user-mapping
It's just a badly formulated question with questionable answers.

I'm thinking D for two reasons: 1. You don't find the phrase "Active Directory Monitoring" anywhere in the documentation (I stand to be corrected); and 2. domain controller monitoring fits with EDU 110 (https://www.routeprotocol.com/palo-altro-edu-110-user-id/). But honestly...this is a stupid question that should have had "Server Monitoring" as the straight answer. I guess the implicit thought is that a domain controller is a server so in a weird way domain controller monitoring = server monitoring.

Selected Answer: A
Path:
Device/User Identification/Server Monitoring 
and then as type: Microsoft Active Directory
So answer A seems correct to me.

comments.content: IDK, take a look at this link: https://www.routeprotocol.com/palo-altro-edu-110-user-id/....my question is, why don't we find Active Directory Monitoring at all in the studyguide? I do find this: In terms of Domain Controllers User-ID, When a user logs into their laptop, which is an Active Directory member, the AD domain controller logs a logon event with the username and IP address of the station." Again, not sure but you won't find "AD monitoring as a term/phrase anywhere (at least that I've found). For that reason I'd go with D.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think D is the most accuratte following, accordin to this,
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/user-id/user-id-concepts/user-mapping/server-monitoring#id89aad143-05b8-4805-8e7c-b123994edd30
None of these answers are correct. The answer you're looking for is "Server Monitoring".
I think the correct answer should be "Server Monitoring"

Selected Answer: D
D is correct you monitor domain controllers

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/user-id/user-id-concepts/user-mapping/server-monitoring.html#id89aad143-05b8-4805-8e7c-b123994edd30

A is correct.
In an AD environment, you can configure the User-ID agent to monitor the security logs for Kerberos ticket grants or renewals, Exchange server access (if configured), and file and print service connections. For these events to be recorded in the security log, the AD domain must be configured to log successful account login events. In addition, because users can log in to any of the servers in the domain, you must set up server monitoring for all servers to capture all user login events.
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/user-id/user-id-concepts/user-mapping/server-monitoring.html#id89aad143-05b8-4805-8e7c-b123994edd30

D:
"...To ensure the most comprehensive mapping of users, you must monitor all domain controllers that process authentication for users you want to map. You might need to install multiple User-ID agents to efficiently monitor all of your resources.>"
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/user-id/map-ip-addresses-to-users/configure-user-mapping-using-the-windows-user-id-agent/install-the-windows-based-user-id-agent

questions.question_text: Which user mapping method could be used to discover user IDs in an environment with multiple Windows domain controllers?
